metadata.title: Surface energy effect on nonlinear free vibration behavior of orthotropic piezoelectric cylindrical nano-shells

sections.text:
M AN
US CR
AC CE
PT ED
*Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 311 87939171 E-mail address: stduxfang@yeah.net (X.-Q. Fang) 1
In this paper, the electro-elastic surface/interface model is introduced to investigate the surface energy effect on the nonlinear free vibration behavior of orthotropic piezoelectric cylindrical nano-shells. On the basis of classical shell theory and von-Karman-Donnell-type geometric nonlinearity, the fundamental equations for vibration are given. By considering the constitute relations for surfaces, the total energy of the orthotropic piezoelectric cylindrical nano-shell is obtained. The governing equations of motion are derived from Hamilton’s principle and solved by using the homotopy perturbation method (HPM). Afterwards, the results without surface effect are compared and validated with the datum available in the literature, and the influences of surface parameters and geometric characteristics on the nonlinear free vibration of the orthotropic piezoelectric cylindrical nano-shell are examined. Key words: Orthotropic piezoelectric material; Cylindrical nano-shell; Surface energy; Nonlinear free
vibration
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
2
1. Introduction
Due to the outstanding piezoelectricity and the unique synergy between the piezoelectric and the semiconducting properties, piezoelectric materials have found a number of applications in smart structures and systems. Different from macroscopic piezoelectric objects, the piezoelectric nano-structures, such as nano-beams, nano-plates and nano-shells, possess not only the excellent piezoelectric effect but also the size-dependent mechanical and physical properties because of their large surface-to-volume ratio, which makes them very attractive in the nano-electro-mechanical systems (NEMS) (Lee et al., 2006; Li et al., 2007).
To better design the nano-shells and make them operate safely, the nonlinear vibration analysis of the nano-shells is quite important. Nano-structures are on such a small scale that the nano-sized effect is convinced to be significant, which has been demonstrated by both atomistic simulations and experimental investigations (Chen et al., 2006; Stan et al., 2007). Hence, the classical continuum theories can no longer be qualified to predict the size-dependent response of nano-structures.
In recent years, the nonlocal piezoelectric theory, surface/interface theory and others were proposed to predict the size-dependent response. In the nonlocal shell theory, the stress and electric displacement at a reference point depend on the strain components and electric-field components at the same position and those on all other points of the nano-structures. To consider the small scale effect, the scale coefficient related with a material parameter is introduced. Based on the nonlocal piezoelectric theory, the electro-thermal-mechanical buckling of double-walled Boron Nitride nanotubes was investigated, and the effects of electric and thermal loads on the critical buckling load were discussed (Ghorbanpour Arani et el., 2012).
In the surface/interface theory, the surface/interface is assumed to be very thin layers adhered to the adjacent media. Based on the first-order shear deformation theory as well as surface/interface elasticity theory raised by Gurtin and Murdoch (1975), the free vibration analysis of nano-shells was carried out and
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
3
the effects of surface parameters on the free vibration behavior of nano-shells were presented (Rouhi et al., 2016). Nevertheless, the surface/interface piezoelectricity, as a unique character for piezoelectric material, is ignored in the surface elasticity theory, which makes it insufficient in predicting the size-dependent response of piezoelectric nano-structures. For example, Wang and Feng (2010) studied the vibration and buckling of piezoelectric nano-wires based on the surface elasticity theory. The effect of surface piezoelectricity, however, was neglected. It can be found that the surface piezoelectric effect may get considerable when the dimension of piezoelectric nano-structures comes into the nanoscale (Tagantsev, 1986). In recent years, to take into account the surface/interface piezoelectric effect, the electro-elastic couple surface/interface model (Fang et al., 2013; Liang et al., 2015) has been introduced to investigate the size-dependent effect on the behavior of piezoelectric nano-structures. By using this coupling surface/interface model, Fang et al. (2014) investigated the dynamic effective property of piezoelectric composites embedded with coated piezoelectric nano-fibers. Based on the Euler-Bernoulli beam theory combining with the electro-elastic surface/interface theory, Yan and Jiang (2011) investigated the surface effect on the electromechanical coupling and bending behaviors of piezoelectric nano-wires.
For piezoelectric cylindrical nano-shells, besides the unique piezoelectricity, the mechanical-electrical coupling surface/interface effect gets considerable because of the size-dependent property, and the nonlinear behavior becomes more prominent when their vibration amplitude is comparable with the thickness of the nano-shell. By introducing the nonlinear higher order terms of strains, the nonlinear electro-thermomechanical buckling behavior of a piezoelectric cylindrical shell was studied, and the critical buckling load for the clamped supported mechanical and free electric potential boundary conditions at both ends of cylinder was given (Mosallaie Barzoki, 2013). However, to our best knowledge, no one has dealt with the nonlinear free vibration analysis of orthotropic piezoelectric cylindrical nano-shells based on the electro-elastic surface/interface theory.
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
4
The primary purpose of this paper is to present a further study on the nonlinear free vibration behavior of orthotropic piezoelectric cylindrical nano-shells based on the electro-elastic surface/interface theory. Hamilton’s principle is employed to get the governing equations and an analytical solution is obtained by using the homotopy perturbation method (HPM). Then some numerical examples are given to illustrate the effect of surface elasticity, surface piezoelectricity and surface dielectricity on the nonlinear free vibration behavior of orthotropic piezoelectric cylindrical nano-shells. 2. Formulation
Fig. 1 depicts an orthotropic piezoelectric cylindrical nano-shell with the length L, thickness h, and mid-surface radius R. A curvilinear system, with its origin located on the mid-surface of the nano-shell, is adopted and the axial, circumferential and radial directions are described by x, θ and z, respectively. Due to the large ratio of surface to volume, the nano-shell is assumed to include a bulk part and two additional thin surfaces (the inner surface S1 and the outer surface S2), as shown in Fig. 1.
For the bulk part, the constitutive relations can be given as

4. Solution procedure
It is assumed that the boundary conditions of the orthotropic piezoelectric nano-shell are simply-supported,
so the following boundary conditions are given:

5. Numerical results and analysis
In this section, the surface energy effect on the nonlinear free vibration behavior of the orthotropic piezoelectric cylindrical nano-shell with simply supported boundary is studied. First of all, to validate the present model, the results obtained from this paper are compared with those available in the literature and then some numerical examples are given to discuss the effect of surface parameters and geometric characteristics on the nonlinear free vibration behavior of the nano-shell. In the following examples, the elastic, piezoelectric, and dielectric constants of the nano-shell (PMN-PT) are chosen as: 11C =229GPa, 12C =135.6GPa, 22C =109GPa, 66C =76.7GPa, 31e =14.66C/m 2, 32e =-9.53C/m 2, 11η =7.588×10-9F/m, 22η =5.667×10-9F/m, and the mass density is ρ =8090kg/m3 (Chen et al., 2009). Those parameters corresponding to the surfaces are taken as: 11 SC = 11C ×P1×10 -9m, 12 SC = 12C ×P1×10 -9m, 22 SC = 22C ×P1 ×10-9m, 66 SC = 66C ×P1×10 -9m, 31 Se = 31e ×P2×10 -9m, 32 Se = 32e ×P2×10 -9m, 11 Sη = 11η ×P3×10-9m,
22 Sη = 22η ×P3×10-9m, where Pi (i=1,2,3) is the factor of surface properties. Besides, the surface residual stress 0 Sσ is 0.01N/m and the vibration mode is selected as (m,n)=(1,4). The dimensions of nano-shell is L=4nm, R=2.54nm and h=0.0254nm.
M
AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
13
5.1 Validation
Since there are no results available in the published literatures for making a comparison with the nonlinear free vibration behavior of orthotropic piezoelectric nano-shells with electro-elastic surface effect, the results are compared and validated for the orthotropic cylindrical shell under classical shell theory, as shown in
Table 1. The properties of the orthotropic cylindrical shell are as below: L=0.4m, R=0.254m, h=0.00254m, 1E =200GPa, 2E =10GPa, 12G =10GPa, 12υ =0.2, ρ =7800kg/m3 (Shen and Yang, 2014). In Table 1, comparison with those of Nowinski (1963), Shen and Yang (2014) and Sofiyev (2016) is presented, it can be found that the present solutions are closer to those obtained from Sofiyev (2016) and the nonlinearity of the previous theory is weaker than that of Shen and Yang (2014), and stronger than that of Sofiyev (2016). On the whole, these comparisons indicate that the present results have good agreement with the available results. 5.2 The effect of surface parameters
Nonlinear analysis of orthotropic piezoelectric nano-shells is crucial for designing the nano-shell and obtaining excellent properties. To find the surface energy effect on the nonlinear behavior, the following numerical examples with various surface parameters are presented. For brevity, the frequency ratio of nonlinearity to linearity is defined as NL Lω − , and the normalized frequency NC Cω − represents the ratio of non-classical nonlinear frequency (with surface effect) to classical nonlinear frequency (without surface effect).
Figs. 2a and b illustrate the effect of surface elastic constant and dielectric constant on the frequency ratio
depending on the thickness, respectively. From Fig. 2a, it can be observed that the frequency ratio NL Lω − becomes small because of surface elastic constant being considered, and for a fixed thickness, it decreases with the increase of surface elastic constant. In addition, the influence of surface elastic constant on NL Lω − can be evidently seen with decreasing thickness and when the thickness of the nano-shell is thick enough, the present result is inclined to the classical case due to the fact that the ratio of surface to volume becomes
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
14
insignificant. In Fig. 2b, all remarks mentioned above can be obtained with one exception that the frequency ratio increases as the surface dielectric constant increases, which is a typical difference between surface elastic constant and surface dielectric constant and it is also demonstrated in the following results. For surface piezoelectric constant, the same conclusions can be drawn in comparison with surface elastic constant, and they are no longer stated.
Figs. 3a and b show the effect of surface elastic constant and dielectric constant on the frequency ratio depending on the dimensionless amplitude, respectively. From Fig. 3a, we can acquire that for a fixed dimensionless amplitude, the frequency ratio decreases with the increase of surface elastic constant and it increases with increasing dimensionless amplitude. The similar results can be obtained for surface piezoelectric constant. However, the effect of surface dielectric constant on NL Lω − is different from other surface parameters. As shown in Fig. 3b, the frequency ratio increases with the increase of surface dielectric constant, but it changes slightly when P3 varies from 0.1 to 1000.
To find the relationship between the normalized frequency and the thickness under different surface elastic constants and dielectric constants, Figs. 4a and b are respectively presented. Different from the phenomena observed in Fig. 2a, in Fig. 4a, the normalized frequency NC Cω − increases with the augment of surface elastic constant and considering surface elastic constant leads to an enhancement in NC Cω − . Similar to the result obtained from Fig. 2a, the normalized frequency also tends to one, i.e., the classical solution when the thickness increases, which proves again that the surface effect is negligible for sufficiently thick nano-shell. By comparing the results in Fig. 4a, here exists one difference in Fig. 4b that the normalized frequency decreases with increasing surface dielectric constant. Similarly, for surface piezoelectric constant, the results are the same with surface elastic constant and they are omitted.
Figs. 5a, b and c respectively show the variation of the normalized frequency versus the dimensionless amplitude under different surface elastic constants, piezoelectric constants and dielectric constants. Among
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
15
theses three figures exists one common characteristic that by taking into account the surface effect, the present results are all bigger than the classical results. As a reasoned case, for a fixed *A , the normalized frequency increases with the increase of surface elastic constant and piezoelectric constant in Figs. 5a and b, but the converse result is obtained for surface dielectric constant in Fig. 5c. Furthermore, in Figs. 5b and c, it is found that the influence of surface piezoelectric constant and dielectric constant on the normalized frequency vanishes with increasing dimensionless amplitude while this is not the case in Fig. 5a. For instance, NC Cω − tends to one with the increase of *A for any surface parameter in Figs. 5b and c, whereas in Fig. 5a, it is close to 1.02, 1.04 and 1.06 when P1 is selected as 0.1, 0.2 and 0.3. 5.3 The effect of length to radius ratio and radius to thickness ratio
Fig. 6 illustrates the variation of the normalized frequency versus the dimensionless amplitude for different length to radius ratios. It is seen that the normalized frequency increases with increasing surface elastic constant for small dimensionless amplitude, while the influence of length to radius ratio can be neglected as the dimensionless amplitude is more than 2. Similarly, for surface parameters P2 as well as P3, the results are all the same with P1.
To find the variation of the normalized frequency versus the dimensionless amplitude for different radius to thickness ratios, Fig. 7 is given. All results mentioned in Fig. 6 are suitable for Fig. 7 with one exception that the effect of radius to thickness ratio becomes insignificant when the dimensionless amplitude is beyond 8. 6. Conclusion
In the framework of the electro-elastic coupling surface/interface theory, surface energy effect on nonlinear free vibration behavior of orthotropic piezoelectric cylindrical nano-shells is studied. Based on classical shell theory as well as von-Karman-Donnell-type geometric nonlinearity, the primary formulations of the problem are obtained. The governing equations of motion are derived from Hamilton’s principle and solved by using the homotopy perturbation method (HPM). The influences of surface parameters and geometric
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
16
characteristics on the nonlinear free vibration behavior are investigated. It is found that for a fixed thickness or dimensionless amplitude, the effect of surface elastic constant on the nonlinear free vibration behavior is similar to surface piezoelectric constant, but opposite to surface dielectric constant. The frequency ratio and the normalized frequency are close to the classical results with increasing the thickness of the nano-shell for a given dimensionless amplitude. At small dimensionless amplitude, the normalized frequency increases with the increase of length to radius ratio or radius to thickness ratio. However, when the dimensionless amplitude is more than 2 or 8, the effect of L/R or R/h on the normalized frequency becomes insignificant.
The detailed analysis on the vibration behavior of orthotropic piezoelectric nano-shells may provide helpful guidelines for the design and application of piezoelectric nanodevices composed of shells in the nano-electro-mechanical systems. Acknowledgements

Research highlights:
1. The model of orthotropic piezoelectric cylindrical nano-shell is constructed. 2. The electro-elastic surface/interface theory for orthotropic cylindrical nano-shell is presented. 3. The total energy of orthotropic piezoelectric cylindrical nano-shell with surface energy effect
is obtained.
4. Some important methods for improving the serving behaviors of piezoelectric nano-shells are
proposed.

referenceMentions.context: Different from macroscopic piezoelectric objects, the piezoelectric nano-structures, such as nano-beams, nano-plates and nano-shells, possess not only the excellent piezoelectric effect but also the size-dependent mechanical and physical properties because of their large surface-to-volume ratio, which makes them very attractive in the nano-electro-mechanical systems (NEMS) (Lee et al., 2006; Li et al., 2007).

Different from macroscopic piezoelectric objects, the piezoelectric nano-structures, such as nano-beams, nano-plates and nano-shells, possess not only the excellent piezoelectric effect but also the size-dependent mechanical and physical properties because of their large surface-to-volume ratio, which makes them very attractive in the nano-electro-mechanical systems (NEMS) (Lee et al., 2006; Li et al., 2007).

Nano-structures are on such a small scale that the nano-sized effect is convinced to be significant, which has been demonstrated by both atomistic simulations and experimental investigations (Chen et al., 2006; Stan et al., 2007).

Nano-structures are on such a small scale that the nano-sized effect is convinced to be significant, which has been demonstrated by both atomistic simulations and experimental investigations (Chen et al., 2006; Stan et al., 2007).
3 the effects of surface parameters on the free vibration behavior of nano-shells were presented (Rouhi et al., 2016).
It can be found that the surface piezoelectric effect may get considerable when the dimension of piezoelectric nano-structures comes into the nanoscale (Tagantsev, 1986).

In recent years, to take into account the surface/interface piezoelectric effect, the electro-elastic couple surface/interface model (Fang et al., 2013; Liang et al., 2015) has been introduced to investigate the size-dependent effect on the behavior of piezoelectric nano-structures.

In recent years, to take into account the surface/interface piezoelectric effect, the electro-elastic couple surface/interface model (Fang et al., 2013; Liang et al., 2015) has been introduced to investigate the size-dependent effect on the behavior of piezoelectric nano-structures.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, the electro-elastic surface/interface model is introduced to investigate the surface energy effect on the nonlinear free vibration behavior of orthotropic piezoelectric cylindrical nano-shells. On the basis of classical shell theory and von-Karman-Donnell-type geometric nonlinearity, the fundamental equations for vibration are given. By considering the constitute relations for surfaces, the total energy of the orthotropic piezoelectric cylindrical nano-shell is obtained. The governing equations of motion are derived from Hamilton’s principle and solved by using the homotopy perturbation method (HPM). Afterwards, the results without surface effect are compared and validated with the datum available in the literature, and the influences of surface parameters and geometric characteristics on the nonlinear free vibration of the orthotropic piezoelectric cylindrical nano-shell are examined.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
